Perhaps you joined step with the cheering throngs. Perhaps you

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

were "over there". At any rate, you remember the rejoicing the
whole world over when the armies of many nations ceased firing and
laid down their arms.
Though six years have elapsed and progressive America is busy
again with invention and money making enterprises, there are those
upon whom the mark of war is indelible—those who can no longer
march because somewhere on a foreign battlefield wounds were received, or those who in the field and base hospitals nursed back
to life wounded ones of the Argonne, of Verdun, and of Chateau
Thierry. They do not forget, nor do those who had brought home
to them sad news from the front. This ,day, November 11th, above
others, will make vivid recollections of the war.
The toll of Hopkins men was great who made the supreme sacrifice that an Armistice Day would come eventually to put a stop to
hostility among warring nations. It is a matter of general concern
that the University takes no cognizance in its Calendar of this fact.
In the future it would seem fitting that appropriate exercises on Armistice Day should be held in memory of our patriotic Hopkins men
resting in Flanders Fields.

COURTESY
At many colleges, the students, as a mark of courtesy and respect for their athletic rivals, rise when the cheering section of the
other institution sings its Alma Mater song. Pittsburgh and St.
John's both played their Alma Mater songs but the Hopkins student
body either sat emotionless or raised a cheer of its own. Hopkins
certainly would raise itself another rung toward ideal sportsmanship
by adopting the custom of rising when the Alma Mater of a visiting
team is played.

A REQUEST
A good response has been made by the campus poets aspiring
for the poetry prize recently offered. There is much of this poetry,
needless to say, not good enough for publication. Yet, whether good
or bad, all must be looked over. The judges selected by The NewsLetter have requested that all contributions be typewritten on standard size paper.

Perhaps you joined step with the cheering throngs. Perhaps you

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

were "over there". At any rate, you remember the rejoicing the
whole world over when the armies of many nations ceased firing and
laid down their arms.
Though six years have elapsed and progressive America is busy
again with invention and money making enterprises, there are those
upon whom the mark of war is indelible—those who can no longer
march because somewhere on a foreign battlefield wounds were received, or those who in the field and base hospitals nursed back
to life wounded ones of the Argonne, of Verdun, and of Chateau
Thierry. They do not forget, nor do those who had brought home
to them sad news from the front. This ,day, November 11th, above
others, will make vivid recollections of the war.
The toll of Hopkins men was great who made the supreme sacrifice that an Armistice Day would come eventually to put a stop to
hostility among warring nations. It is a matter of general concern
that the University takes no cognizance in its Calendar of this fact.
In the future it would seem fitting that appropriate exercises on Armistice Day should be held in memory of our patriotic Hopkins men
resting in Flanders Fields.

COURTESY
At many colleges, the students, as a mark of courtesy and respect for their athletic rivals, rise when the cheering section of the
other institution sings its Alma Mater song. Pittsburgh and St.
John's both played their Alma Mater songs but the Hopkins student
body either sat emotionless or raised a cheer of its own. Hopkins
certainly would raise itself another rung toward ideal sportsmanship
by adopting the custom of rising when the Alma Mater of a visiting
team is played.

A REQUEST
A good response has been made by the campus poets aspiring
for the poetry prize recently offered. There is much of this poetry,
needless to say, not good enough for publication. Yet, whether good
or bad, all must be looked over. The judges selected by The NewsLetter have requested that all contributions be typewritten on standard size paper.
